title: Phone Talk
summary: This lesson teaches essential vocabulary for talking about phones, including different phone types, common features, and actions you take when making or receiving calls.

sections.heading: Phone Types and Features
sections.content: This section covers different types of phones and their key features with descriptions and examples.

examples.definition: A phone that stays in one place and is connected by a cable.
examples.example: You can call me on my landline in the evenings.

examples.definition: A phone you can carry with you and use anywhere.
examples.example: I usually carry my mobile in my back pocket.

examples.definition: A mobile phone that can connect to the internet and run apps.
examples.example: I was able to check my emails on my smartphone.

examples.definition: A system that records messages when you miss a call.
examples.example: Jim didn’t answer the call, so I left a message on his voicemail.

examples.definition: The strength of the phone connection.
examples.example: You’ll get a stronger signal if you go out into the garden.

examples.definition: The sound your phone makes when someone calls.
examples.example: That’s my phone ringing. I recognise the ringtone.

examples.definition: A small card in your phone that stores your phone number and information.
examples.example: All your personal data is stored on the SIM card inside your phone.

examples.definition: A cable used to power your phone’s battery.
examples.example: I was unable to charge my phone because I had left my charger at home.

sections.heading: Phone Call Actions
sections.content: This section includes vocabulary for actions you take when using a phone, like making and receiving calls.

examples.definition: To press numbers on a phone to make a call.
examples.example: I picked up the phone and started to dial his number.

examples.definition: To contact someone by phone.
examples.example: I’ll ring you as soon as I get home.

examples.definition: To answer a call.
examples.example: Tom’s phone was ringing, so he picked it up and said “Hello.”

examples.definition: To wait on a call for a short time.
examples.example: Of course, you can speak to Tony. Hold on, and I’ll go get him.

examples.definition: To connect a person’s call to another person.
examples.example: The helpful receptionist put me through to the manager.

examples.definition: To wait on the phone after your call has been answered.
examples.example: Please hold the line while we try to connect you to one of our sales assistants.

examples.definition: When you are waiting to speak to someone who is on another call.
examples.example: When I finally got through to the bank, they put me on hold for ages.

examples.definition: When the person you are calling is already talking to someone else.
examples.example: Joe’s line is busy; I’ll try calling him later.

examples.definition: To return a call to someone who called you earlier.
examples.example: Sam called while you were out. I told him you’d ring him back this evening.

examples.definition: A call that you did not answer.
examples.example: I saw a missed call from my friend, so I called her back.

examples.definition: To end a phone call.
examples.example: I said goodbye and hung up the phone.

examples.definition: When your phone is disconnected in the middle of a call.
examples.example: We were unable to finish our conversation because we were cut off in the middle of our call.
